content.webTitle: Indigenous services plead with federal government to rethink cuts

fields.headline: Indigenous services plead with federal government to rethink cuts
fields.bodyText: The social services sector is pleading with the federal government to stop the cuts to Indigenous organisations as frontline services continue to reel at the extent of funding losses through the Indigenous Advancement Strategy. The Indigenous affairs minister, Nigel Scullion, announced last week that more than $680m in grants had been assigned to 964 organisations to run 1,297 programs under the strategy. The IAS is the result of more than half a billion dollars in cuts in the 2014 budget, and consolidates more than 150 Indigenous affairs programs and policies into five broad areas. Guardian Australia has spoken with numerous organisations who have lost all funding, had their usual annual budgets cut or had their budgets renewed at the same levels for 12 to 18 months. The chief adviser on Indigenous affairs, Warren Mundine, told the ABC there were $8bn worth of applications so he was “not surprised” that many missed out. Wendy Morton, executive director of the Northern Territory Council of Social Services, said the sector was “probably the most uncertain it has ever been” during her 10 years at the council. “Our message to the government is this is not the area to make savings,” she said. “There are other areas you can make savings and hitting those most disadvantaged, those most vulnerable and often those in poverty is not the area they should be seeking to save the money.” Speaking in Darwin on Monday afternoon, Morton said organisations had already been scaling back programs over the past few months and had to make early decisions to cut programs to give staff warning. She pointed to the North Australian Aboriginal Justice Agency which has said it will soon be refusing to take on new clients. Many of those organisations who have been granted funding have received a reduced amount or funding for a short time – 12 to 18 months secured, which Morton said was a “major issue”. “It’s all incredibly uncertain and it is very difficult; one: to keep staff when they don’t know if they have a job in a year’s time and for many they’ll start looking for alternative employment; and two: what programs to begin with families. If you’re going to get the most out of working with that individual family you need a consistency in the person working with them and to know that in 12 months’ time or 18 months’ time they’re still going to get the support.” The next step for successful applicants is to enter into negotiations with the federal government, but Morton said organisations needed to decide whether it was worth running the program on a smaller amount than that they applied for. “We’ve heard of a range of children and family programs which have also been cut across the territory,” Morton said. “There’s also been previous cuts over the last few months through the department of social security and those cuts have impacted on financial counselling, families and parenting programs, across a broad spectrum of services. “This comes on top of the territory government making significant cuts over the last two years, particularly in the children and family services. And young people in the territory – particularly Aboriginal young people – are the most vulnerable … and yet this is the sector we seem to be cutting the most.” The Darwin-based Amity Community Services was one of the latest organisations to receive a knockback, for its volatile substance and alcohol and drug outreach service. The service cost $480,000 a year – 20% of its budget – and it worked with police, youth services and the retail sector in addressing volatile substance abuse such as aerosol sniffing among local youth. The IAS knockback came at the cost of four jobs, two of them held by Indigenous people, the opposition spokeswoman Natasha Fyles said on Monday, and would put young people “further at risk”. “This is a key frontline service working hard to direct disadvantaged young people into treatment services and to get them to re-engage with their families, school or employment,” Fyles said. Morton said as far as she knew no other organisation had picked up the service Amity was losing, although that had happened with other organisations. Scullion last week dismissed suggestions that frontline services had been cut. “We have been very mindful in making decisions as part of this funding round and remain committed to improve the lives of Indigenous people,” he said. “The Abbott government has committed $860m dollars in IAS funding to ensure this happens.” The Macdonnell regional council said on Monday it was being allocated less than its previous annual budget to deliver an expanded service. A statement from the federal Labor senators Nova Peris and Warren Snowdon claimed Indigenous ranger and Caring for Country programs had also lost funding. “By defunding councils and Aboriginal organisations Mr Abbott is taking away the services and jobs Aboriginal people need to live in their communities, on their country, with dignity,” Peris said. On Friday it was revealed the national peak body for Indigenous legal services will close in June, after it was not granted funding through the IAS. Fourteen Family Violence Prevention Legal Services branches maintained their funding, but only for 18 months. All seven state and territory attorney generals wrote to their federal counterpart, George Brandis, at the weekend warning that federal plans for legal assistance would set back moves made against family violence and Indigenous disadvantage by decades.
